review_blob: Very nice.  Exceptionally smooth and balanced. Very similar to ODells IPA, which I like very much as well.  Malt and yeast balance much better than Stone, which I hold as the standard of a "pure" west coast IPA.  Appearance is also distinguished by lasting white head and lacing, nice orange color, and excellent activity. Might be the best overall balanced IPA Ive had yet.

Tasty brew for the style.  Quite reminescent of all those German Bocks I quaffed back in the day  My only real complaint comes against the style itself.  Pilsener Bocks simply dont have the substance to carry the high alcohol content without it being objectionably noticeable.  It always comes across as a spiked pilsener, which is simply not a good thing IMO. In spite of that complaint, this is a very good offering for the style, and a nice change of pace for one accustomed to strong IPAs.

Distinct taste of lemon right up front -  not at all objectionable.  Traditional European pils taste hides subtly in the background.  Couldnt detect it at first for the lemony attack.  Lacing is extraordinary for a pils, and the body is much more robust as well.  Not a bad pilsener at all.  Much more character than most Ive tried.  Very refreshing after a winter (its very springlike here in NM today) of heavy IPAs.  Nice playoff football watching quaff, for sure.

Quite decent offering in a macro-brewed light beer.  Picked up a twelve on a hunch when I was in the mood for some light-weight sipping brew, and was not disappointed.  This would really be quite excellent in the heat of the summer, and would be an excellent change of pace for holiday gatherings as well.  Nice introduction to wheat beer, which can tend to be a little overwhelming to a novice.  Hats off to Budweiser for daring to offer a very tasty alternative to the mainstream light beer market.  This is really quite an innovative move on their part.
UPDATED: NOV 29, 2009

Interesting, but like the other SN IPA Ive tried, tastes NOTHING like an IPA.  Some sort of mild fruity pineappple/grapfruit thing going on across the middle of the palate, but little else.  A good beer, but certainly nothing remarkable.  Hops?  I couldnt taste any.  Tastes more like a confused strong amber/ice bock to me.

Lots of chocolate in this one, especially for an amber.  Sort of an Irish Stout meets and Irish Red IMO.  Balanced and tasty for a change pace, but certainly nothing to go out of your way for.  Sam Adams Irish Red tastes better, is easier to find, and costs less.  Need I say more?

Im confused.  Maybe my six pack somehow bypassed the hops process.  This beer was as unobjectionable as it is unremarkable.  Surprising, since I loved their IPA.  Keep a six of this on hand to satisfy your mainstream beer friends and impress them with your knowledge of micro brews.  Other than that, pass.
UPDATED: JAN 30, 2009

Bottle, Emporia Kansas.  Average and unadventurous, albeit well-balanced APA.  Very "midwest" to my tastes - conservative and unlikely to offend anyone, just not likely to make anyone scream its praises either.  Unfortunately, Im not much into balanced APAs or IPAs, hence the low rating.

Actually, not as absolutely as piss poor as I thought it would be.  Color, aroma, and taste were all acceptable for something coming from Budweiser.  Nothing Ill pay money for again, but not a drain pour.  The worst part of this whole experience was drinking the 3.2 version of this shit in a shitty motel room in Weathorford OK of all the fucked up holes in the universe, and knowing this was the BEST shit that could be found in town.  Why would ANYONE choose to live here?

What the FUCK is up with the apostrophe warning?  Is this website based in OK per chance?

I refer back to this one every now and then as a benchmark to see how my tastes have changed.  The malt and hops tastes in the commercial deScription are always right on, but the weak, watery, character that the ad guys wont tell you about is always there too.  Maybe I just cant take lagers anymore, I dunno.  If youre used to slamming light beers all day, this will definitely be a move up.  If youre used to sampling even the moderately better brews out there, save your money.

Very decent red.  Nice fluffy white head, impressive lacing, beautiful color color, fragrant nose, and excellent bitter-sweet taste, true to the style.  Not over the top ABV wise either.  Not complex in any way like an Arrogant Bastard for instance, but not everyone appreciates such over the top brews anyway.  Very good everymans brew.

Although Im a devotee of Stone IPA and have not been a fan of Full Sail offerings Ive tried in the past, I must admit this stuff is one of the more balanced and better IPAs Ive tried. A nice malty presence for an IPA (and as a true Stoney, I view a hefty malt presence as offensive), without being overly heavy.  The bitter floral hops notes are all there, but not over the top.  My bottle was marked at 6.0 ABV, and I find that to be the ideal.  All in all, very good stuff.  I dont like many IPAs, but this one is very good indeed.

FINALLY found this one for $11.25 @ sixer in a HyVee gocery store in Council Bluffs IA of all places.  I was knocked out by the taste, and am now on a quest to find more in the Albuquerque-Santa Fe region of NM.  Local dealers give me phantom sightings ("we JUST had some"), but no actual results just yet.  I might have to rent a truck and haul it in myself.  This stuff was mothers-milk smooth with a 6% ABV kick.  Smoothest brew Ive drunk that I can remember.  If this was freely available, Id drink nothing else (well, at least for a while).  Exceptional!

Finally found this stuff.  Tried both the PA and the ESB in bottles from a HyVee in Council Bluffs IA for $11.25 @ sixer at that.  I had heard many good reviews of the Fuller ESB in particular, and I was quite impressed with both.  The London Pride PA seemed a bit weak in the knees at 4.7%, but on the plus side, that would make it quite sessionable (albeit at a VERY steep price).  Very complex as advertised, especially when compared to typical US West Coast offerings, which are typically bolder by a large measure.  Fullers is now on my "must have" radar when its available, as its most decidedly not in the NM, Colorado region that I frequent.

A good, almost tasteless alternative for a hot summer day, when you mostly need water for hydration, but want a minimal amount of alcoholic kick and taste as well.  Bud fills that niche well, but not much else.  Best taste in its category, although thats not saying much either.  Ive always liked the packaging though.  Definitely best in class.  Their advertising is always first rate too.  Hey, cant blame em for trying!  Their sales figures obviously dont lie.

Not a fan of dark beers, but I read up on Stouts and Porters (couldnt find a definitive difference bewteen the two) before comparing SN Stout and SN Porter head to head today in honor of St. Pats.  This is simply no contest.  If you like this style, SN Stout is head, shoulders, elbows, hips, and knees above this subpar offering in every way.  Overcarbonated, watery, and lacking in character and complexity.  What more can I say?  Very nearly a drain pour.

Not a fan of this style, but in honor of St. Pattys day, Im doing a head to head with this and a SN Porter from the bottle, along with some corned beef and cabbage.  Both are similar in appearance (the beers), with the Porter notably more carbonated in an unappealing way.  In short, even though the Stout was served several degrees colder, it simply blows away the Porter in complexity, depth, and all things dark and mysterious.  In fact, the Porter would be better labeled a Stout Light if truth in advertising meant anything.  Skip the Porter, try the Stout if youre into this sort of thing.

Been a while since I had an ESB, but this ones better than most.  Im an IPA guy now, so this tastes a little tame for me, but Ill give it a go anyway.  Nice amber color and white head with decent lacing and staying power.  Very nice change of pace from traditional SN brews, which all taste very similar to me.  Not as bitter as the ESBs I remember, but not as thin and watery either.  I doubt the ESB guys will call this one world class for its lack of defining character, but I doubt SN intended it for that anyway. 6% ABV is just right too.  Since this ones a seasonal, Ill probably lay in a case or two for future review.  SN always produces good stuff, and this ones no exception.
UPDATED: JAN 18, 2008

Reminds me of my first German Pils; thin, bitter, and stinky, just not as good.
Decent for the style, but really now; why would anyone drink more than one of these, regardless of what else was available (Listerine anyone)?
Im guesing that in a blind taste test (minus all the "original Pilsener" hype) this one would score MUCH lower than it has.
Sorry, I find nothing remarkable here, other than peoples amazing response to hype.

Im a big Stone fan like many posters on this board, but Im probably going against the grain when I say that I think this is one of their best.  No, this ones not over the top in the hops dept. like their famous IPAs, and I think it might almost be misclassified as an American pale ale as well.  What it is, is an exceptionally well balanced pale/amber ale, with no overwhelmingly pronounced single characteristic.  Its actually what I expect every Oktoberfest beer to be,  only to be so quickly dissappointed once the first cap comes off.

This is an EXCEPTIONAL beer, whether or not its true to the American pale ale style or imagined Stone standard for hoppiness or not.  I love it!
UPDATED: SEP 26, 2008

A pleasant surprise!  Best Mendocino offering Ive tried.  Not over the top alcohol-wise like their Eye of the Hawk and IPA.  Quite good overall; one of the better ambers Ive tried.  No weird aftertastes, like many of this style seem to have. Ill probably be coming back to this one often.  I think the 52 current rating is considerably understated.
UPDATED: JAN 8, 2008

Nice, medium-high alcohol, holiday fest-brew.  Not as hoppy as Ive come to expect and prefer, but a good middle of the road offering nonetheless, thats more likely to appeal to the broad variety of palates that gatherings this time of year are likely to include.  SN has gradually become the "quality Budweiser" of American brews in my opinion, an altogether good thing I think.  Lets hope they dont water down their offerings as well to attract an even wider market share.
UPDATED: OCT 10, 2007

Wow - Stone does it again!  Picked up two bombers - dont usually like wheats, hedged my bet with Stone IPA - wish Id bought some more.  This ones like an over the top wheat/IPA or something.  All the cloudiness and complexity of a good wheat, with the typical hops bite of a Stone.  The alcohol comes through a little too clearly, but other than that, a VERY fine brew.  Definitely gonna pick up a case or two for long-term appreciation.
UPDATED: JAN 30, 2009

Decent, different take on a Wheat.  As most here have noted, this one doesnt really clearly fall into distinct any category, so just take it for what it is.  Sort of a wheat-malt distinctly lemony pilsener maybe?  Nice change-up offering for summer, but I wouldnt go out of my way looking for it or anything.  Try one at a friends house if possible - saves buying (and not finishing) a sixer.

Sampled this head to head vs a Sierra Nevad a Wheat.  Two different approaches, but very comparable results.  Widmer is cloudier and truer to the style, although definitely lacking in complexity of character, as many other reviewers have noted.  Even so, a good Wheat for those who dont enjoy the extreme fruitiness of the higher rated Wheats.

Never been a fan of wheats, but this is a good one.  Tastes almost like an exotic fruit juice.  Frothy white head and decent lacing, opaque tangerine color, spicy and fruity flavor.  This one might make me a convert.  VERY nice.
One of Petes better offerings.  Decent, quickly diminishing head on pour, and good activity after.  Nice summer offering with minimal hops bite.
UPDATED: FEB 5, 2007
UPDATED: JAN 30, 2009
UPDATED: JUL 22, 2006
UPDATED: JUL 28, 2006
Uugh!  Stacked this one up against Boulder Beer Sundance Amber last night.  To say the least, I disagree whole-heartedly with the majority opinion on these two!

Very nice.  A long time since Ive tried this midwestern staple.  Light and refreshing like an American pilsener should be, but, unlike the majors, with actual taste and character.  I could see downing a bunch of these on a hot summers night without the bloat and hangover that comes with a strong ale.

From a bottle or a can, simply foul, offensive, overly carbonated crap - a Budweiser by any other name!  Pours flat and goes south from there.  Might be good as a drain cleaner - Ill let you know how it works out.  CERTAINLY not meant for human consumption.

Dont know why this one gets such a bad rap.  When Im in the mood for a light american-style pilsener thats as light as a light beer, but without the watered down taste, Hamms is my first choice every time.  And at $5.30/12 pack, how can you go wrong?   I still remember the Hamms bear commercials - from the land of sky blue waters - MUCH more original than todays current shlock!  This is a VERY drinkable light american Pilsener for a VERY REASONABLE price!  Drink some.
UPDATED: JAN 16, 2007

A dead ringer for Rogue Dead Guy Ale, with an extra 1% kick.  Sweet to a fault, frothy, lazy, orange, and cloudy.  I love it; unfortunately, I probably wont remember it in the morning.   I like this style in the winter when I want something to drink and finish the night with, that doesnt leave me all acidic and in need of food before bed.  Rich, hearty, filling, and quite satisfying.  Ill buy more of this, for sure.
beer_name: Mendocino Eye of the Hawk Select Ale

review_blob: I like these German lager offerings.  Nice, warm, fairly but not overly bitter taste, well balanced all around.  All the same, after growing accustomed to the fine US west coast ales, its quite apparent that time has passed the Europeans by.  Fine for nostalgias sake, otherwise stick to the US stalwarts.
UPDATED: SEP 1, 2006
Banana malts ala New Belgium Abbey.  Sweet, low activity, low complexity.  Not bad, not great.  Buy Deschutes Quail Springs IPA instead.

A somewhat lighter version of Sierra Nevada Pale to my taste.  The finishing hops are a little more prominent in this brew, mostly due to lack of underlying complexity.  Nice golden/copper color, but quite unexceptional activity and head.  Very good nonetheless!  All of the Deschutes brews that Ive tried (Twilight and IPA) have offered a very interesting and satisfying change of pace.  Not mainstream, but very good.

For those who find most pales overly hopped, this brew might be just what youre looking for.  Agreeable, mild flavor; small, disappointing head and activity.  Very mild, albeit rich, soft flavor.  Notably little hops bitterness. Lack of complexity and definitive character relegate this brew to the grocery store class.  Decent if youre not looking to spend a lot and want something thats sure not to offend anyone at your gathering.
UPDATED: AUG 22, 2006
